results.title: The Power of Water
results.creator_credit: Chris McCullough, Peter Butt and Film Australia
results.brief_description: We all use electricity in our everyday lives. The Snowy Mountains Hydro Electric Scheme can produce essential peak load for all of New South Wales, Victoria and the Australian Capital Territory within minutes, and water to the Murray and Murrumbidgee irrigation system. “The power of water” looks at the workings and history of the Snowy Mountains Scheme from the early years of construction through to the most recent technological developments. A comprehensive guide on the Scheme introduces the processes which allow Australia’s greatest engineering project to produce a valuable and efficient form of energy - power from water.

results.title: The Power of positive influence
results.brief_description: This video training package (with accompanying trainer’s guide) aims to provide managers and team leaders with the skills to assert a positive influence on their team members. As a leader in any situation in any organisation, it is helpful to gain a better understanding of human nature and why people behave in certain ways. While motivation ultimately comes from within, managers can influence what their staff are motivated to do by providing a positive work environment, building confidence and self esteem, and personal empowerment.

results.title: The Power of mentoring
results.brief_description: Mentoring is where an experienced individual invests time, energy and personal knowledge to assist another person. This management title discusses successful mentoring behaviours and follows two main mentoring relationships and their development. Also shown is a mentoring situation which isn’t working, demonstrating that mentoring requires an equal input from both partners. A 51 page training program accompanies this title.

results.title: The Power makers
results.creator_credit: Lee Robinson and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: The film depicts a working day for a dredge operator, a train driver, a foreman and a turbine attendant at the open cut brown coal mine and power station at Yallourn, Victoria. These men join with thousands of others to convert the brown coal into electricity; the technical processes involved are shown incidentally.

results.title: The Powder room
results.creator_credit: Ann Kennard, Michael Allder and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: The Powder room journeys through a number of ladies restrooms throughout Canada and the United States, interviewing women and capturing through their tales an often invisible part of our cultural life. Through observations of her own, director Ann Kennard felt the need to document this female ritual and in doing so manages to explore an important way in which women socialise and impart information about their personal lives. The intimacies and morals of women find their way into the bathroom and therefore find a voice and an antidote to their isolation. Subjects discussed include sexuality, orgasm, dating, sex, boyfriends, infidelity, teenage pregnancy, sexual attitudes, body image, sexual practices.

results.title: The Post
results.creator_credit: Hugh Piper, Helen Barrow, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Evershine and Film Australia
results.brief_description: This very interesting documentary follows the workings of an independent English language newspaper in Cambodia, the Phnom Penh Post, established in 1991 by its American editor-in-chief, Michael Hayes and published every fortnight to a readership of about 5000. The highly respected Post is run by 20 staff including 8 journalists who work in teams of one Khmer/one westerner chronicling some of Cambodia’s most politically turbulent moments with insight and compassion. At the time of making this film, there was political instability, economic chaos, no democratic government in place and the Post was struggling to survive when out of left-field, news was received that oppposition leaders to the military regime, Prince Ranariddh and Sam Raisy were to return. This was good news not only for Cambodia, but for the staff at the Post. Through interviews and following the Post journalists on their daily hunt for a story, we are given a close-up view of the challenges faced by an independent newspaper and the suffering and tragedy that still exists in the lives of the Cambodian people as they strive for peace and reconciliation.

results.title: The Portable power saw: how to use it safely
results.brief_description: An instructional film on how to use power saws both in industry and at home. Shows how to select the correct blades, how to fit them properly and the proper safety precautions.

results.title: The Population explosion
results.brief_description: A look (in 1960) at the grave consequences of the abnormally high rate of growth of the world’s population. Reporter Howard K. Smith.

results.title: The Pony
results.creator_credit: Lawrence Cherry, Nicholas Balla and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: In the hearts of two Saskatchewan farm children nothing could take the place of a pony. But their father’s eight hundred-hectare mechanized wheat farm seemed to have no place for one. How their wish was eventually fulfilled beyond expectation makes a heart-warming Christmas story. Cast includes Mary McNeil, George Russell, Helen Bothwell, William Cornish, Norman Ericson, Georgia Gibbs, Frank Hanson.

results.title: The Pond and the city
results.creator_credit: Wheaton Galentine, Willard Van Dyke, Knickerbocker Productions and The Conservation Foundation
results.brief_description: Looks at the need for conservation of natural resources. Points out that water and forest resources are not inexhaustible, but must be carefully protected. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.
